de.galgtonold.jollydayandroid.impl

Class XMLManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.galgtonold.jollydayandroid.HolidayManager
      • de.galgtonold.jollydayandroid.impl.XMLManager
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    XMLManagerJapan

    public class XMLManager
extends HolidayManager
    Manager implementation for reading data from XML files. The files with the name pattern Holidays_[country].xml will be read from the system classpath. It uses a list a parsers for parsing the different type of XML nodes.

    • Method Detail

      • getHolidays

        public java.util.Set<Holiday> getHolidays(int year,
                                          java.lang.String... args)
        Returns the holidays for the requested year and hierarchy structure. Calls Set with the configuration from initialization.
        Specified by:
        getHolidays in class HolidayManager
        Parameters:
        year - i.e. 2010
        args - i.e. args = {'ny'}. returns US/New York holidays. No args -> holidays common to whole country
        Returns:
        the list of holidays for the requested year

      • getHolidays

        public java.util.Set<Holiday> getHolidays(org.joda.time.ReadableInterval interval,
                                          java.lang.String... args)
        Returns the holidays for the requested interval and hierarchy structure. Calls getHolidays(year, args) for each year within the interval and returns a list of holidays which are then contained in the interval.
        Specified by:
        getHolidays in class HolidayManager
        Parameters:
        interval - the interval in which the holidays lie.
        args - a String object.
        Returns:
        list of holidays within the interval

      • init

        public void init(java.lang.String calendar)
        Initializes the implementing manager for the provided calendar. Initializes the XMLManager by loading the holidays XML file as resource from the classpath. When the XML file is found it will be unmarshalled with JAXB to some Java classes.
        Specified by:
        init in class HolidayManager
        Parameters:
        calendar - i.e. us, uk, de

      • init

        public void init(java.net.URL url)
        Initializes the implementing manager for the provided URL. Initializes the XMLManager by loading the holidays XML file as resource from the classpath. When the XML file is found it will be unmarshalled with JAXB to some Java classes.
        Specified by:
        init in class HolidayManager
        Parameters:
        url - the URL, to a file containing the calendar

        Note 1: This can be omitted, in which case the default behavior of loading from the classpath with a specific name will be used

        Note 2: If this parameter is not omitted, then it may be a path to a file (relative or absolute) or a URL spec (such as http://somehos/somefile, or ftp://somehost/somefile or whatever is supported by the URL Stream Handlers installed on the JVM)

      • logHierarchy

        Logs the hierarchy structure.
        Parameters:

      • getConfigurationFileName

        public static java.lang.String getConfigurationFileName(java.lang.String country)

        Returns:

      • validateConfigurationHierarchy

        protected static void validateConfigurationHierarchy(Configuration c)
        Validates the content of the provided configuration by checking for multiple hierarchy entries within one configuration. It traverses down the configuration tree.
        Parameters:
        c - a Configuration object.

      • getCalendarHierarchy

        public CalendarHierarchy getCalendarHierarchy()
        Returns the configured hierarchy structure for the specific manager. This hierarchy shows how the configured holidays are structured and can be retrieved. Returns the configurations hierarchy.
        i.e. Hierarchy 'us' -> Children 'al','ak','ar', ... ,'wv','wy'. Every child might itself have children. The ids be used to call getHolidays()/isHoliday().
        Specified by:
        getCalendarHierarchy in class HolidayManager
        Returns:
        Current calendars hierarchy
